tit.e: Bakuhan-taisei (the feudal system characteristic of the shogunate)

sen.j: 幕藩体制（ばくはんたいせい）とは、近世日本の社会体制のあり方を、幕府（征夷大将軍）と藩（大名）という封建制度的主従関係を基点にとらえた歴史学上の概念である。
sen.e: "Bakuhan-taisei" is a historical concept of social system of Early Modern Japan viewed basically from feudal homage between bakufu (shogunate) (or seii-taishogun, literally "great general who subdues the barbarians) and han (clans) (or daimyo, meaning "feudal lords").

"Bakuhan-taisei" is a historical concept of social system of early modern Japan viewed basically from feudal homage between bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (or seii-taishogun, literally "great general who subdues the barbarians) and han (domains) (or daimyo, meaning "feudal lords").

sen.j: 戦前段階には狭義に政治体制自体を指していたが、戦後の歴史学の進展に伴い、近世日本の社会体制全体の特色を示す概念として使われるようになった。
sen.e: Before the World War II, the term meant a political system itself in the narrow sense, but along with development of the historical science in the post-war era, the term has become to mean a concept that indicates features of the entire society system of the early modern Japan.

sen.j: 江戸幕府を全ての武士の頂点とし、最高の統治機関としながらも、各大名がそれぞれの領地においてある程度独立した統治機構（藩）を形成していることと、米などを現物で納めさせて年貢とする石高制をその基礎においていることが特徴である。
sen.e: It was characterized with the Edo Shogunate as the supreme govering institution at the top of warriors, and yet with each feudal lord which maintained kind of independent govering structure in its own territory (han or domain), as well as with the tax system based on annual yield of rice, Kokudaka-sei, whereby tax is paid by rice and other actual goods.

It was characterized with the Edo bakufu as the supreme governing institution at the top of warriors, and yet with each feudal lord which maintained somewhat independent governing structure in its own territory (domain), as well as with the tax system based on annual yield of rice, Kokudaka-sei, whereby tax is paid by rice and other actual goods.

sen.j: 諸大名を親藩、譜代大名、外様大名に分け、参勤交代や改易によってこれを統制した。
sen.e: Daimyo (feudal lords) were classified into Shinpan Daimyo (descendants of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA), Fudai Daimyo (hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa family) and Tozama Daimyo (non-Tokugawa feudal lords), all of which were controlled by Tokugawa shogunate through Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords were required to spend every other year in their residences in Edo) and Kaieki (change or forfeit of ranks).

sen.j: 幕藩体制を形作る諸制度は初代将軍徳川家康以降、2代徳川秀忠、3代徳川家光の時代に、鎖国体制や知行制、村請制などが確立されていった。
sen.e: Various social systems to build up Bakuhan-taisei (the feudal system featured by Shogunate at the top in the Edo Period), including systems of sakoku (national isolation), chigyo (enfeoffment) and murauke (village wide, collective responsibility for tax payment) were established under the reigns of the first to third shogunates, namely Ieyasu, Hidetada and Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 江戸時代には商人資本の成長や農村への商品経済の浸透、それらによる身分制の変質など、村落共同体の動揺は一揆や打ちこわしを招き、幕府や諸藩は幕政改革や藩政改革を行い再編を試みる。
sen.e: During the Edo Period, growth of merchant capitals and penetration of a commodity economy to agricultural villages contributed to the transformation of hierarchy of village communities, which, however, caused such turmoils in the society as uprising peasants and destructive riots and compelled both Bakufu (shogunate) government and Han (local domain) governments to try to reform their political systems.

sen.j: 幕末には幕府は鎖国政策を改めて開国し、朝廷権威も伸長して公武合体路線が進められる。
sen.e: In the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, bakufu (shogunate) government ended its seclution policy and opened the country to the world, and along with the extension of the authority of the Imperial court, reconciliation between Imperial court and shogunate was promoted.

sen.j: 大政奉還、王政復古 (日本)により解体された。
sen.e: Bakuhan Taisei (the feudal system of shogunate in Japan) was dissolved by Taisei Hokan (the transfer of power back to the Imperial court) and Osei Fukko (the restoration of imperial rule in Japan).

sen.j: 明治初期には旧藩による統治は維持されるが、中央集権政策のもと版籍奉還、廃藩置県により幕藩体制は終結する。
sen.e: Although the govering structure by old han (feudal domains) was maintained for a while in the early Meiji Period, Bakuhan Taisei was eventually brought to the end through a series of Hanseki Hokan (the return of lands and people to the Emperor) and Haihan Chiken (the abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) under the new policy of centralization.
